## Answer
        

 When answering reference ONLY if applicable source with (Source <insert number>). Answer based on the mentioned sources in the Context answer the Question.

Solvency II is the common name for **Directive 2009/138/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 November 2009** on the taking-up and pursuit of the business of insurance and reinsurance. It establishes a harmonised EU-wide regulatory framework for insurance and reinsurance undertakings, setting out requirements on capital adequacy, risk management, and supervisory oversight to ensure the financial soundness of these undertakings and the protection of policyholders (Source 1, Source 3, Source 4).

 * Title: Directive 2009/138/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 November 2009 on the taking-up and pursuit of the business of Insurance and Reinsurance (Solvency II)
* Header 1: TITLE I

* Header 2: *CHAPTER VI*

 extract:

 **Surplus funds**


1. Surplus funds shall be deemed to be accumulated profits
which have not been made available for distribution to policy
holders and beneficiaries.


2. In so far as authorised under national law, surplus funds
shall not be considered as insurance and reinsurance liabilities to
the extent that they fulfil the criteria set out in Article 94(1). 


 


        
## Answer
        

 When answering reference ONLY if applicable source with (Source <insert number>). Answer based on the mentioned sources in the Context answer the Question.

If surplus funds are legally the property of the insurer, any obligation to share them with policyholders depends on the contractual terms, legally binding arrangements, or national law.  

For example, in certain structures such as **ring-fenced funds** or **experience funds**, policyholders may be entitled to a **minimum predefined proportion of the profits** generated, as set out in the policy documentation. These profits can be distributed through additional benefits or lower premiums, with any remaining balance potentially going to shareholders (Source 1, Source 2).  

Where no such contractual or statutory profit-sharing mechanism exists, surplus funds are considered **accumulated profits not made available for distribution to policyholders** and remain at the insurer’s disposal, subject to Solvency II own funds classification rules (Source 3, Source 4).

## Answer
        

 When answering reference ONLY if applicable source with (Source <insert number>). Answer based on the mentioned sources in the Context answer the Question.

Under Solvency II, insurance and reinsurance undertakings must meet detailed supervisory reporting requirements, which include:

- **Regular Supervisory Reporting**: This must include the *Solvency and Financial Condition Report* (SFCR) as per Article 300, along with any equivalent publicly disclosed information and any updated versions (Source 1).  
- **Capital Requirement Information**: The regular supervisory report must contain quantitative information on the Solvency Capital Requirement (SCR) split by risk modules (standard formula) or risk categories (internal model), expected developments of SCR and Minimum Capital Requirement (MCR) over the business planning period, and, if required, an SCR estimate under the standard formula (Source 2).  
- **Deadlines**:  
  - Regular supervisory report: at least every 3 years, and after the transitional period, no later than 14 weeks after the financial year-end.  
  - ORSA supervisory report: within 2 weeks after concluding the assessment.  
  - Annual quantitative templates: within the same deadlines as the regular supervisory report (Source 3).  
- **Additional Disclosures**: Reports must include any material changes to SCR and MCR during the period, reasons for such changes, details of any non-compliance with MCR (including duration, amount, causes, consequences, and remedial measures), and unresolved non-compliance amounts at the reporting date (Source 4).

 What is the impact on contract boundary if future premium fall outside of the contract boundary ? 


        
## Context

 extract:

 **Boundary of an insurance or reinsurance contract**


1. The boundaries of an insurance or reinsurance contract shall be defined in accordance with paragraphs 2 to 7.


2. All obligations relating to the contract, including obligations relating to unilateral rights of the insurance or
reinsurance undertaking to renew or extend the scope of the contract and obligations that relate to paid premiums, shall
belong to the contract unless otherwise stated in paragraphs 3 to 6.


3. Obligations which relate to insurance or reinsurance cover provided by the undertaking after any of the following
dates do not belong to the contract, unless the undertaking can compel the policyholder to pay the premium for those
obligations:


(a) the future date where the insurance or reinsurance undertaking has a unilateral right to terminate the contract;


(b) the future date where the insurance or reinsurance undertaking has a unilateral right to reject premiums payable
under the contract;

## Answer
        

 When answering reference ONLY if applicable source with (Source <insert number>). Answer based on the mentioned sources in the Context answer the Question.

If future premiums fall outside of the contract boundary, they and the related obligations **do not belong to the contract** for Solvency II purposes. This occurs, for example, where the insurer has a unilateral right to terminate the contract or reject premiums, or where it can reprice premiums/benefits so they fully reflect the risk (Source 1, Source 4).  

Only premiums and obligations **within** the contract boundary are included in the projection of cash flows for valuation; those outside are excluded from the best estimate liability calculation (Source 2).

## Answer
        

 When answering reference ONLY if applicable source with (Source <insert number>). Answer based on the mentioned sources in the Context answer the Question.

Voor het berekenen van het SCR voor concentratierisico moet je de bedrijfsobligatie en de covered bond als **twee afzonderlijke single name exposures** behandelen.  

Volgens de regels voor specifieke blootstellingen worden covered bonds (mits credit quality step 0 of 1) aangemerkt met een eigen relatieve drempelwaarde (_CTᵢ_) van 15% en **worden zij beschouwd als een aparte single name exposure, los van andere blootstellingen naar dezelfde tegenpartij** die de covered bond heeft uitgegeven (Source 1).  

Dit betekent dat je:  
- Voor de bedrijfsobligatie de concentratierisicoberekening uitvoert op basis van de normale drempelwaarden en risicofactoren voor die categorie.  
- Voor de covered bond een aparte berekening maakt met de specifieke drempelwaarde van 15% (en alleen als deze aan de kwaliteitsvereisten voldoet).  

De resultaten voor beide exposures worden vervolgens meegenomen in de totale SCR-berekening voor marktrisico-concentratie.

 **Spread risk on bonds and loans**


1. The capital requirement for spread risk on bonds and loans _SCR_ _bonds_ shall be equal to the loss in the basic own
funds that would result from an instantaneous relative decrease of _stress_ _i_ in the value of each bond or loan _i_ other than
mortgage loans that meet the requirements in Article 191, including bank deposits other than cash at bank referred to
in Article 189(2)(b).


2. The risk factor _stress_ _i_ shall depend on the modified duration of the bond or loan _i_ denominated in years ( _dur_ _i_ ). _dur_ _i_
shall never be lower than 1. For variable interest rate bonds or loans, _dur_ _i_ shall be equivalent to the modified duration of
a fixed interest rate bond or loan of the same maturity and with coupon payments equal to the forward interest rate.

 extract:

 Using the templates to be received under the regular supervisory reporting as
required by Article 35 of Directive 2009/138/EC and based on the valuation as
described under Article 75 thereof, the numerator is calculated by screening the
second category of the Complementary Identification Code which corresponds to the
category of corporate bonds. An additional screening is needed to identify the issuer
economic sector in order to figure out the corporate bonds issued by the companies

classified as other than financial and insurance activities. The issuer economic sector

is identified based on the NACE code (acronym used to designate the various

statistical classifications of economic activities developed since 1970 in the European
Union).


The denominator corresponds to the sum of the amount listed in the assets category
as ‘investments’ and the amount listed in the assets category under ‘Cash and Cash
Equivalents’ in the balance-sheet.

 **Specific exposures**


1. Exposures in the form of bonds as referred to Article 52(4) of Directive 2009/65/EC (covered bonds) shall be
assigned a relative excess exposure threshold _CT_ _i_ of 15 %, provided that the corresponding exposures in the form of
covered bonds have been assigned to credit quality step 0 or 1. Exposures in the form of covered bonds shall be
considered as single name exposures, regardless of other exposures to the same counterparty as the issuer of the covered
bonds, which constitute a distinct single name exposure.


2. Exposures to a single immovable property shall be assigned a relative excess exposure threshold _CT_ _i_ of 10 % and a
risk factor _g_ _i_ for market risk concentration of 12 %.


3. Exposures to the following shall be assigned a risk factor _g_ _i_ for market risk concentration of 0 %:


(a) the European Central Bank;
